or concealing. Gwen Ifill reviews Donald Rumsfeld 's memoir, "Known and Unknown" Known and Unknown," a hefty and heavily annotated accounting and defense of his life in public service. Never much of a handwringer, I don't spend a lot of time in recriminations, looking back or second-guessing decisions made in real time with imperfect information by myself or others, he writes. But hand-wring he does, in repeated blasts of Donald Rumsfeldian score-settling that come off as a cross between setting the record straight and doggedly knocking enemies off pedestals.
